questions.text: On investing for infertility the male partner was found to have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. How many of the following are associated with this condition ? Azoospermia/severe oligospermia Low LH, Low FSH Low LH, high FSH Low testosterone Low prolactin level Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,4

Highyeild:

In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism: Gonadotropins (FSH, LH) decrease leading to a decrease in testosterone. Decreased levels of testosterone have an inhibitory effect on spermiogenesis i.e. azoospermia. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism can be congenital or acquired. Congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is divided into anosmic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Kallmann syndrome) and congenital normosmic isolated hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). Low blood testosterone levels and low pituitary hormone levels confirm the hypogonadotropic hypogonadism diagnosis. A prolonged stimulated intravenous GnRH test can be useful. It is important to consider that the first endocrinological change to occur during puberty is an increase in LH, which initially occurs more in amplitude than in frequency and only at night; subsequently, both LH and FSH levels increase at night and during the day until adult levels are reached. It is difficult to differentiate between HH and delayed puberty, as low gonadotropin and testosterone levels are found in both conditions. Therefore, a definitive HH diagnosis must be confirmed only after the patient is 18 years of age.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following is more commonly associated with Kallman’s syndrome ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anosmia

Highyeild:

Kallman’s Syndrome: anosmia is one of the most characteristic findings. Type of congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with associated dysfunction of olfactory bulbs. Associated with numerous genes ( g. , KAL1, KAL2, etc.) Failed migration of GnRH-producing neurons from the developing brain including passage to the cribriform plate. Lack of GnRH results in ↓ LH, FSH, testosterone, and sperm count.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false. Option A - Syndactyly can be an isolated finding, or it can be found in association with other abnormalities (eg, polydactyly, cleft hands, ring constrictions, and craniofacial syndromes ). It is a shared feature of more than 28 syndromes, including Poland, Apert, and Holt-Oram syndromes. Option C - Precocious puberty is when a child's body begins changing into that of an adult (puberty) too soon. When puberty begins before age 8 in girls and before age 9 in boys, it is considered precocious puberty. Option D

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which one of the following constitutes the Modified Biophysical Profile?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AFI + NST The modified biophysical profile was developed to simplify the examination and reduce the time necessary to complete testing. It consists of NST & AFI. The AFI is derived by adding the largest vertically measured pocket from each uterine quadrant. If either NST or the AFI is abnormal or in the presence of a nonreactive NST+AFI less than 50 mm, a complete BPP or an OCT is performed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA Biophysical profile score For each component presence = 2 points, absence 0 points Tone at least one episode of active limb, trunk or hand extension with return to flexion Movement at least 3 discrete body/limb movements (active continuous considered as single movement) Breathing at least one episode of at least 30 seconds duration (includes hiccups) Amniotic fluid at least one single vertical pocket >2 cm Heart rate at least 2 acceleration of - 10 beat x 10 sec (24-28 weeks) - 15 beat x 15 sec (28-34 weeks) - 20 beats x 20 sec (>34 weeks) Modified BPS - Amniotic fluid index - Reactive FHR Composite score of 5 variables - Normal 10, 8 (PNM=1/1000) - Equivocal (PNM=7-10/1000) 8 with oligohydramnios 6 Abnormal (PNM=12-300/1000) 6 with oligohydramnios 4,2,0 Score of 4 immediate retesting - for 30 min Persistent score of 4, or less - immediate delivery Correlation of Last NST pattern with mode of delivery Sl. No. Mode of delivery Reactive NST (N=80) Non Reactive NST (N=30) No % No % 1 Normal Vaginal 43 53.75 14 46.6 2 Vaginal Breech 4 5 0 0 3 Forceps application (a) Fetal distress (b) Others (c) Total 1 1 2 1.25 1.25 2.5 1 1 2 3.33 3.33 6.66 4 LSCS (a) Fetal distress (b) Others (c) Total 6 25 31 7.5 31.25 38.75 7 7 14 23.3 23.3 46.6 Component Definition Fetal movements 3 body or limb movements Fetal tone One episode of active extension and flexion of the limbs; opening and closing of hand Fetal breathing movement episode of >= 30 seconds in 30 minutes Hiccups are considered breathing activity. Amniotic fluid volume single 2 cm x 2 cm pocket is considered adequate. Non-stress test 2 accelerations > 15 beats per minute of at least 15 seconds duration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cost-effective regular screening procedure advised for pregnant women ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ECHO

Highyeild:

ECHO is not a component of the routine pregnancy screening regimen. It is very costly and thus done only when suspected in symptomatic patients after ruling out other possibilities.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are false. Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - The screening test is called an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), which takes about 2 hours . It involves having a blood test in the morning when you have not had any food or drink for 8 to 10 hours (though you can usually drink water, but check with the hospital if you're unsure). Option B - Option C - This test is used to screen for syphilis . The bacteria that cause syphilis are called Treponema pallidum. Your healthcare provider may order this test if you have signs and symptoms of a sexually transmitted illness (STI). Syphilis screening is a routine part of prenatal care during pregnancy.

questions.text: High-risk HPV does not cause which of the following ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laryngeal Papillomatosis

Highyeild:

Among the many strains of HPV, 16, 18, 31 and 33 are considered high-risk strains due to their capacity to cause carcinomatous changes (eg. genital, rectal, oral CA) in the majority of the affected population. Most Prevalent - HPV 16 Low risk subtypes - 6, 11

Extraedge:

HPV: Double-stranded DNA oncovirus. Especially HPV-16 and HPV-18 HPV infects the immature basal layer of the cervical epithelium in areas of epithelial breaks, leading to basal cell replication through the synthesis of oncogenic proteins E6 and E7. E6 inhibits p53, a tumour suppressor protein. E7 inhibits retinoblastoma protein (Rb), a tur suppressor protein. Persistent HPV leads to intraepithelial lesions. Persistent HPV leads to squamous intraepithelial lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the Kassowitz rule ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital Syphilis

Highyeild:

Colles' or Baumis law: A newborn child affected with congenital syphilis, even though it may have symptoms in the mouth, never causes ulceration of the breast which it sucks, if it is the mother who suckles it, though continuing capable of infecting the nurse. In other words, a child born to an apparently asymptomatic mother with no signs of venereal symptoms, and who presents with syphilis after a few weeks would infect the healthiest nursemaid, but not its mother. Profeta's law - At birth, an infected infant may appear healthy and may not develop signs till it is some weeks old, but in other cases, signs are present at birth. Diday-Kassowitz law: Kassowitz’s law is an empirical observation used in the context of congenital syphilis stating that the greater the duration between the infection of the mother and conception, the better the outcome for the infant . If a woman with untreated syphilis has a series of pregnancies, the likelihood of infection of the fetus in later pregnancies becomes less. The greater the duration between the infection of the mother and conception, the better the outcome for the infant.

questions.text: Regarding the pathogenesis of preeclampsia, which of the following is incorrect ?

options.label: A
options.text: There’s an increase in SFLT-1 and a decrease in PIGF.

options.label: B
options.text: Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis, haemorrhage and end-organ damage seen in pre-eclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of pre-eclampsia

options.label: D
options.text: There’s a decrease in TXA2 and an increase in the PGI2-TXA2 ratio in pre-eclampsia

questions.correct_answer: D. There’s a decrease in TXA2 and an increase in the PGI2-TXA2 ratio in pre-eclampsia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There’s a decrease in TXA2 and an increase in the PGI2-TXA2 ratio in pre-eclampsia

Highyeild:

There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI2) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA2) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia. The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by: Failure of 2nd wave of trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading to immunological maladaptation. Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy. Genetic factors and epigenetic influences. The basic pathology is endothelial dysfunction and vascular spasm that affects vessels supplying all organs including the brain. kidney. uterus. etc. This ischemia leads to necrosis, haemorrhage, and end-organ damage of these organs. Reduced angiotensinase activity and increased sensitivity of vessels to angiotensin II which is a vasopressor. Reduced production of nitric oxide due to endothelial dysfunction. It normally acts as a vasodilator and inhibits platelet aggregation and thrombus formation. Increased production of endothelin 1 by endothelial cells. It is a potent vasoconstrictor.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - There’s an increase in SFLT- 1 and a decrease in PIGF. sflt1 significantly inhibited VEGF- and PlGF-induced vasodilation at a level observed in patients with severe preeclampsia. These data suggest that circulating sflt1 in preeclamptic patients might oppose physiologic vasorelaxation , thus contributing to hypertension. Option B - Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis, haemorrhage and end-organ damage seen in pre-eclampsia. Option C - Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of pre-eclampsia - circulating levels of nitrite are decreased in patients with preeclampsia . These data support the concept that diminished nitric oxide synthesis contributes to the pathophysiologic changes seen in preeclampsia.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding MgSO4 in preeclampsia?

options.label: A
options.text: MgSO4 should be given for 24 hours after a convulsion

options.label: B
options.text: MgSO4 in renal failure loading dose can be given but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

options.label: C
options.text: MgSO4 covers seizures and hypertension simultaneously

questions.correct_answer: C. MgSO4 covers seizures and hypertension simultaneously
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MgSO4 covers seizures and hypertension simultaneously MgSO4 does exert specific anticonvulsant action on the cortex but does not lower the BP.

Highyeild:

Magnesium is mainly used in preeclampsia due to its specific anticonvulsant action and neuroprotective action on the cortex. It acts as a membrane stabilizer and reduces motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine and blocks neuronal calcium influx. It is not used to treat hypertension, although it shows some hypotensive action by decreasing vascular response to vasopressors.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and D are true. MgSO4 does exert specific anticonvulsant action on the cortex but does not lower the BP. Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: MgSO4 should be given until 24 hrs after the last seizure (in postpartum seizure) or delivery, whichever is later. For recurrent seizures, 2 g IV bolus is given in the above regimen. Option B: MgSO4 inhibits uterine contractility but is dose-dependent (only above serum values of 8-10 mEq/L ). Option D: Magnesium is cleared almost exclusively by renal excretion. But in renal failure, the initial loading dose of magnesium sulfate can be safely administered regardless of renal function. Only the maintenance dose needs to be altered according to the renal function. This is because the loading dose is responsible for reaching therapeutic levels. but the maintenance doses are responsible for maintaining steady states.

Table:

#MANTRA Regimen Loading dose Maintenance dose Pritchard's 20 ml of 20% (4 gm) slow in 3-5 min; +10 ml of 50% (5 gm) deep IM* on each buttock (10 gm) 10 ml of 50% (5 gm) deep IM on alternate buttock every 4 h Dhaka 4 gm IV (20%) given over 15 min and 2 gm as 50% solution given IM in each buttock 2.5 gm as 50% solution IM on alternate buttock every 4 h Zuspan 4 gm IV (20%) in 100 ml fluid given over 15 to 20 min 1 gm/h in 100 ml fluid IV Sibai 6 gm IV over 20 min 2 gm IV infusion *IM=Intramuscular, IV-Intravenous Observations and care during MgSO4 infusion: Continuous CTG monitoring if ≥ 26 weeks gestation (if < 26 weeks gestation, perform 30 minutely auscultation) Maternal observations: Respiratory rate (and pulse oximetry if available) every 30 min. BP 30 minutely Maternal pulse hourly Urine output hourly Reflexes at the completion of the loading dose and then every 2 hours

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Manning's score except ?

options.label: A
options.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone FHR, amniotic fluid volume

options.label: B
options.text: Can tell us about the fetal outcome and fetal pH

options.label: C
options.text: Score <4 is consistent with fetal pH <7.2 & score <2 is 100% predictive of fetal acidemia

options.label: D
options.text: The score is consistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

questions.correct_answer: D. The score is consistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The score is consistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

Highyeild:

The fetus receives a score of zero or two points for each parameter of the Biophysical Profile. A score of 6/8 or 8/8 is normal. A complete BPP includes the addition of electronic fetal monitoring (nonstress test) for a total score of 10 points. A score of 8/10 or 10/10 is considered normal. A score of 6/10 is equivocal and 4/10 is abnormal. A fetus may score 8/8 or 10/10 in <30 minutes, but any other score requires a full 30 minutes of observation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are true.

Table:

#MANTRA Parameters Minimal normal criteria Score NST Reactive 2 Fetal breathing movement >/= 1 episode lasting >30 sec 2 Gross body movement >/=3 discrete body/limb movement 2 Fetal muscle tone >/= 1 episode of extension with return of flexion 2 Amniotic fluid >/= one 2*2 cm pocket 2 manning's score manning scoring- (manning= BATMAN) B-Breathing A-Amniotic fluid volume T-Tone M-Movements A-and N-NST Biophysical profile score For each component presence = 2 points, absence 0 points Tone at least one episode of active limb, trunk or hand extension with return to flexion Movement at least 3 discrete body/limb movements (active continuous considered as single movement) Breathing at least one episode of at least 30 seconds duration (includes hiccups) Amniotic fluid at least one single vertical pocket >2 cm Heart rate at least 2 acceleration of - 10 beat x 10 sec (24-28 weeks) - 15 beat x 15 sec (28-34 weeks) - 20 beats x 20 sec (>34 weeks) Modified BPS - Amniotic fluid index - Reactive FHR Composite score of 5 variables - Normal 10, 8 (PNM=1/1000) - Equivocal (PNM=7-10/1000) 8 with oligohydramnios 6 Abnormal (PNM=12-300/1000) 6 with oligohydramnios 4,2,0 Score of 4 immediate retesting - for 30 min Persistent score of 4, or less - immediate delivery

questions.text: Regarding PPH, which of the following statement is incorrect ?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery

options.label: B
options.text: Initial replacement by colloids, 4 times the amount of blood lost

options.label: C
options.text: Chorioamnionitis, multiple pregnancies and prolonged labour are the risk factors

options.label: D
options.text: By adding 500ml for each 3 volume % drop in Hct, the volume of blood loss can be calculated

questions.correct_answer: B. Initial replacement by colloids, 4 times the amount of blood lost
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Initial replacement by colloids, 4 times the amount of blood lost

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are true. Initial replacement is done by crystalloids in PPH.

Table:

#MANTRA 4T's CAUSES TONE: uterine atony TISSUE: retained placenta TRAUMA: lacerations, uterine rupture cloTTing: coagulopathy Hemorrhage Blood Loss Timing PPH (ACOG¹) > 500 mL after vaginal delivery > 1000 mL after cesarean delivery Severe PPH (ACOG¹) >2000-2500 mL after delivery PPH (WHO 6 ) > 500 mL after delivery Within the first 24 hours after delivery Severe PPH (WHO 6 ) > 1000 mL after delivery Within the first 24 hours after delivery Antepartum Bleeding from the vagina As of 24 weeks' gestation Primary PPH Bleeding occurring at delivery Within the first 24 hours after delivery Secondary PPH Any amount of excessive bleeding from the birth canal 24 hours after delivery and up to 6 weeks' postpartum MOH > 2000-2500 mL Antenatal or postpartum CHORIOAMNIONITIS Maternal Infection Chorioamnionitis is a maternal infection that affects the placenta and the membranes that surround the growing baby. A pregnant woman can get chorioamnionitis when bacteria move upward through her vagina and into her uterus. Mismanaged chorioamnionitis can cause neonatal infection, preterm labor, HIE, cerebral palsy. periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), and other injuries and complications.

questions.text: Regarding the management of a diabetic woman in labour, which of the following is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Elective C-section has no effects in reducing the incidence of brachial plexus injury

options.label: B
options.text: GDM pt. should be given morning insulin at the time of induction as usual

options.label: C
options.text: Regular insulin is given by IV infusion pump

options.label: D
options.text: Capillary blood glucose levels are maintained at the app. 100mg/dl

questions.correct_answer: B. GDM pt. should be given morning insulin at the time of induction as usual
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GDM pt. should be given morning insulin at the time of induction as usual

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are true. Option A - Usual dose of intermediate-acting insulin is given at bedtime and the morning dose is withheld IV infusion of normal saline solution is started on the side. Option C - Regular insulin is administered by IV infusion of 1.25 U/h.

Table:

#MANTRA INSULIN MANAGEMENT DURING LABOR: HYPERGLYCEMIA INSULIN to GIVE INSULIN ADJUSTMENT Fasting PG remains > 5.0 mmol/L Intermediate-acting neutral protamine Hagedorn insulin pork; (NPH) - human or Potentially insulin glargine or detemir might be used Adjustments to the bedtime insulin dose to be made tonight if glucose monitoring result is: <4.2 reduce bedtime dose by 2 units 4.3-4.9 maintain present bedtime dose 5.0 5.3 increase bedtime dose 1 unit 5.4-6.0-increase bedtime dose 2 units 6.18.0 increase bedtime dose by 4 units > 8.0 - increase bedtime dose by 6 units Postmeal PG remains > 7.8 mmol/L BEFORE MEALS: Regular Rapid-acting (aspart, lispro) Adjustments to tomorrow's pre-meal insulin dose if today's 1h-post-meal result for that meal is: <5.5 - decrease pre-meal dose by 2 units 5.6 7.2 maintain present pre-meal dose 7.2-10.0 increase pre-meal dose by 1 unit >10.0 - increase pre-meal dose by 2 units for the following day's doses Insulin Management during Labor and Delivery Usual dose of intermediate-acting insulin is given at bedtime. Morning dose of insulin and breakfast is withheld. Intravenous infusion of normal saline is begun. Once active labor begins or glucose levels fall below 70 mg/dl, the infusion is changed from saline to 5% dextrose Glucose levels are checked hourly using a portable meter allowing for adjustment in the infusion rate. Regular (short-acting) insulin in administered by intravenous infusion if glucose levels exceed 140 mg/dl.
